flashCards.backSide: Specifies the types of media that are acceptable for the response. It informs the server about the preferred content type of the client.
Identifies the user agent (such as a browser or a crawler) making the request, which helps the server provide content tailored to the user's device or application.

Indicates the domain name of the server being requested. It is mandatory for HTTP/1.1 requests and is used to route the request to the appropriate server when multiple domains are hosted on the same IP address.
Used to include credentials (e.g., a token or username and password) for authentication purposes. It allows the client to access protected resources on the server.
Specifies the media type of the request body (e.g., 'application/json' or 'text/html'). It informs the server about the format of the data being sent in the request.
Contains previously set cookies that the client sends back to the server. This helps maintain session state and user authentication information between requests.
Indicates the URL of the referring page or the previous page that led the user to the current request. It is often used for analytics and tracking purposes.
Specifies the origin (protocol, domain, and port) of the page that initiated a cross-origin request. It is used to enforce the same-origin policy for security.
